bwwExcerpt: "Heisenberg" begins with a pretty woman having just kissed a stranger, a much older man, on the back of the neck in a London railway station. After some initial awkwardness, a relationship develops. Their encounter is a version of the familiar Hollywood gambit of a man and woman "meeting cute," and what follows is an equally improbable, if sweet, romantic fantasy. It all goes down very easily, thanks to director Mark Brokaw and, especially, the actors in Simon Stephens' two-character play, which
